awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary trends and ecological drivers of eye reduction in bat flies (Hippoboscoidea)
awd_abstract_narration:
Vision is an important sensory mode, and through vision, animals including humans can detect and process their orientation in space, make out shapes, sense time, move and navigate, or detect color. Vision is complex, and different solutions for vision exist across the animal kingdom, such as compound eyes in insects versus simple eyes in humans. However, many features enabling vision, such as genes, structures and signaling methods, are similar across animals. This is why insects are a useful model for our general understanding of the processes involved in making eyes functional. This project focuses on members of a group of insects that consistently live at low light levels, in a place where food and mates are close by and need not be visually recognized over large distances. The eyes of these insects have been dramatically reduced from the fully developed daylight version, but they are still functional. In studying the process of this reduction over evolutionary timeframes, this project aims to understand the sequence of events and which stimuli led to the reduction (or loss) of visual structures, and what minimum level of organization and complexity is required to maintain a functional eye. Results of this interdisciplinary research will contribute to our understanding of the robustness and adaptability of complex biological systems. This study is also directly relevant to the fields of phylogenetics, evolutionary systems biology, neurobiology and bioengineering. In addition to scientific advancement, this project will reach and train students from diverse backgrounds at all levels of education, including middle/high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Research results will be integrated into inquiry-based education modules for middle and high school teachers. 

This project uses phylogenomic, histological, and molecular methods to test several hypotheses regarding the evolution of reduced, yet functional, eyes in parasitic bat flies. Bat flies are an ideal system for this type of study because 1) all species have reduced or lost eyes, and there are variations among species in the degree of reduction; 2) the group is derived from fully visual, free-living predatory ancestors, and extant species can be studied for comparative analyses; and 3) due to life history characteristics of the group, bat flies trace two distinct ecological niches - the developmental niche (where pupae are deposited) and the host niche (where adult bat flies occur in association with bats) - that introduce variations in host proximity and light environments among species. Comparative studies of the variation in host and developmental niches among species, and the resulting structural patterns in micro- and macro-eye anatomy across the phylogeny will allow for the testing of hypotheses related to 1) which ecological features are driving the evolution of eye reduction and 2) how different physical domains (e.g. macromorphology, micromorphology, and gene expression) evolve relative to these driving forces.

por.por_cntn:
The phenomenon of eye reduction and loss is an often-cited feature of species from disparate ecological habitats (i.e., caves, deep-sea) and ecological strategies (i.e., parasitism).  However, few studies have investigated the evolution of eye-loss to understand how the mechanisms of reduction across biological levels of organization (e.g., external eye morphology, internal retinal anatomy, gene expression, and genomic structure) are integrated while maintaining eye functionality.  Bat flies, consisting of two families (Diptera, Streblidae and Nycteribiidae) of obligate, blood-feeding, bat parasites, are an ideal organismal group for studies of eye loss across these levels because all species have reduced eyes, there are variations in eye reduction among species, and as a group they are derived from fully visual free-living predatory ancestors.  In this research, studies of bat fly visual systems including external eye morphology (e.g., eye shape and size, number of facets, individual facet area, facet diameter), internal retinal arrangement, expression of phototransduction genes, and genomic architecture were integrated for a comprehensive characterization of the mechanisms of eye reduction across scales embedded in a comparative phylogenetic framework.   

To date, the research has led to the publication of eight peer-reviewed papers, one book chapter, and one M.S. thesis, as well as an additional nine peer-reviewed publications from researchers in the field as part of a special issue of Integrated and Comparative Biology associated with a conference symposium organized around the topic of eye reduction and loss.  The research was presented to the scientific community, in educational settings, and to the public through twelve presentations related to the evolution of eye reduction and loss, particularly in cave settings. The research funding supported the training of one research technician, two M.S. students, one post-baccalaureate student, two undergraduate students, and one high-school student in methods related to SEM imaging, standard molecular lab techniques, and the bioinformatics associated with large transcriptomic and genomic datasets.  The research also led to collaborations with the Bernice Pauahi Bishop Museum, Honolulu, Hawaiʻi and nine additional national and international researchers, five of whom were early career female researchers (four post-doctoral researchers and one assistant professor) at the time of collaboration.  The data generated from the funded research includes SEM images and associated data on eye characteristics from species representing 67% of the described genera in the two families (64% Nycteribiidae genera, 69% of Streblidae genera); 16 transcriptomic datasets (4 species of Nycteribiidae, 12 species of Streblidae); and 54 genomic datasets (27 species of Nycteribiidae, 26 species of Streblidae, 1 outgroup species).

From these studies, we have discovered that within the two families of bat flies there are at least eight lineages which have independently lost eyes completely. There are also at least two genera, Basilia and Trichobius, where there are variable number of facets among individuals within a species, and in Basilia there is one species where facet numbers consistently vary within a single individual between eyes. Externally, the eye fields vary greatly in size, shape, and number of facets.  Internally, the receptor fields under each remaining facet consist of fused rhabdoms, which is a hallmark of species living in dim light environments and distinct from the ancestral fly receptor arrangement. In at least one species, Trichobius frequens, the receptor field in each of the eight facets remaining in each eye consists of variable numbers of receptor cells (11-18 cells) that have peak sensitivity to blue-green wavelengths of light (peak absorbance = 487 nm). At the molecular level, light detection in animal visual systems is achieved by opsin proteins bound to a light sensitive derivative of vitamin A.  A typical fly expresses six different opsins, each with a distinct sensitivity to different wavelengths of light. Most of the bat fly species studied retained a single opsin gene in their genome (Rh1), and gene expression and physiological studies confirmed this gene was expressed in bat fly eyes.  In some species, particularly within the Nycteribiidae, some species also retained a second opsin gene (Rh6) in their genomes, although there is currently no data to suggest this gene was expressed.  Overall, these results demonstrate that there are distinct patterns of reduction at each level of structure investigated that maintain functional light detection as eyes are lost.
